intro: Myriopus salicifolius, commonly known as the willow-leafed myriopus, is a perennial herb native to southern Australia. It belongs to the family Poaceae, commonly known as the grass family, and is characterized by its narrow, willow-like leaves. The plant typically grows in sandy or gravelly soils and is often found in coastal areas. Its flowering stems bear small, spike-like inflorescences, which produce tiny, wind-pollinated flowers. Myriopus salicifolius is adapted to arid conditions and plays a role in stabilizing sandy soils in its native habitat.
